title: The Mississippi Abortion Case at the Supreme Court: What You Should Know
sub_head: The nation’s highest court has agreed to revisit a core precedent stemming from its landmark Roe v. Wade
body:
The question of abortion rights is making a return to the Supreme Court, with justices on Monday agreeing to hear a challenge to a Mississippi law that bans abortions after about 15 weeks of pregnancy.
More directly than in other recent abortion cases, the court is positioned to revisit the long-recognized constitutional right to an abortion before fetal viability that stems from its landmark 1973 Roe v. Wade decision.
Here are some questions and answers about the case and its implications.
The Supreme Court said it would hear the case titled Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization. At issue is a challenge to Mississippi’s Gestational Age Act, a 2018 law that prohibited doctors from performing abortions after 15 weeks of gestation except in medical emergency or in case of severe fetal abnormality.
Jackson Women’s Health Organization, the only licensed abortion facility in the state, sued to overturn the law. A district court and a federal appeals court said the law was unconstitutional, prompting Mississippi’s appeal to the Supreme Court.
